channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2024 The New York Times Company

item.title: In Rural China, ‘Sisterhoods’ Demand Justice, and Cash
item.description: Growing numbers of Chinese women are challenging a longstanding tradition that denies them village membership, and the lucrative payouts that go with it.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Wang
item.media:description: A village in Guangdong Province, China. Women in rural areas are deprived of land rights if they marry outside their village.

item.title: Brazil’s X Ban Upended Digital Businesses Overnight
item.description: The ban on Elon Musk’s X has dealt a blow to Brazilians whose livelihoods depended on internet followings they had amassed for years, and which disappeared overnight.
item.dc:creator: Ana Ionova
item.media:description: A Brazilian user of the social network X, formerly known as Twitter, browsing posts on a phone in Brasilia last month.

item.title: Edmundo González, Opposition Candidate, Flees Venezuela
item.description: Edmundo González, who is widely considered to have won July’s disputed presidential election, was facing an arrest warrant.
item.dc:creator: Genevieve Glatsky and Orlando Mayorquín
item.media:description: Law enforcement officials outside the Argentine ambassador’s residence in Caracas, where six opposition leaders have been sheltering since March.

item.title: Kuwait Turns to Power Cuts as Climate Change Strains Its Grid
item.description: The Persian Gulf nation has instituted rolling blackouts to cope with surging summer electricity demand, stirring frustration among citizens.
item.dc:creator: Yasmena Almulla and Vivian Nereim
item.media:description: Power lines in Kuwait City in June. The ministry of electricity, water and renewable energy has increased scheduled power cuts as summer temperatures have soared.

item.title: Iran Sent Ballistic Missiles to Russia, U.S. and European Officials Say
item.description: U.S. and European countries had warned of sanctions if Iran provided weapons that could be used against Ukraine. President Biden’s lame-duck status could hamper a response.
item.dc:creator: Steven Erlanger, Julian E. Barnes and Michael Crowley
item.media:description: A drone in the distinctive triangle shape of an Iranian-made Shahed-136 in the sky over Kyiv, Ukraine, during a Russian drone attack in 2022.

item.title: Israel Strikes Schools Turned Shelters in Jabaliya, Gaza Medics Say
item.description: Israel said it had launched a “precise strike” against Hamas militants operating from two school compounds in northern Gaza, as the family of a slain American lashes out at Israel.
item.dc:creator: Erika Solomon and Rawan Sheikh Ahmad
item.media:description: Palestinians mourn over bodies in Deir al Balah, in central Gaza, on Saturday.

item.title: Super Typhoon Yagi Makes Landfall in Vietnam After Pounding Southern China
item.description: At least four people have died and thousands were evacuated after Yagi, one of the strongest storms to hit northern Vietnam, brought powerful winds and torrential rains.
item.dc:creator: John Yoon and Isabella Kwai
item.media:description: The city of Haiphong on Saturday before Yagi made landfall in northern Vietnam.

item.title: Tony Blair’s Advice on Leadership: Tend to Your Legacy
item.description: In an interview, the former British prime minister discussed his new book ‘On Leadership,’ the dysfunction of U.S. politics, and deflected questions about Elon Musk’s influence.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.category: Blair, Tony, Institute for Global Change
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.media:description: “I didn’t do enough, frankly,” Tony Blair said about the framing of his legacy, adding, “It’s ultimately going to be determined in years to come by people you’ve never met.”

item.title: In Papua New Guinea, Pope Francis Hears Plea for Climate Action
item.description: Pope Francis is visiting Papua New Guinea, which has been exploited for its natural resources and is imperiled by rising sea levels.
item.dc:creator: Emma Bubola
item.media:description: Pope Francis meeting with Bob Dadae, the governor general of Papua New Guinea, in Port Moresby on Saturday.

item.title: Ukrainian Street Artist Documents War Against Russia, One Stark Mural at a Time
item.description: Using ruins as his canvas, Gamlet Zinkivskyi has captured life in wartime Ukraine in dozens of grim, gripping and harshly beautiful paintings. “Broken, but invincible,” read one captioned work.
item.dc:creator: Constant Méheut
item.media:credit: Finbarr O'Reilly for The New York Times
item.media:description: The street artist Gamlet Zinkivskyi, who has painted murals in cities across eastern Ukraine, walking past one of his first works made after Russia’s invasion in his hometown, Kharkiv.

item.title: Indonesia Is One of the World’s Biggest Sources of Catholic Priests
item.description: A seminary on Flores, a Catholic-majority island in Indonesia, ordains so many priests that a lot of them go abroad to serve the faithful.
item.dc:creator: Sui-Lee Wee, Muktita Suhartono and Nyimas Laula
item.media:credit: Nyimas Laula for The New York Times
item.media:description: Celebrating Mass on a Sunday at St. Paul Major Seminary, on Flores, an island in Indonesia.

item.title: In France Rape Trial, a Daughter Talks of Torment
item.description: In court, the woman said she was traumatized not only by what prosecutors said happened to her mother but also by fear that she herself might have been abused.
item.dc:creator: Catherine Porter
item.media:description: Caroline Darian and her mother, Gisèle Pelicot, with Ms. Darian’s two brothers on either side of them at the courthouse in Avignon, France, on Monday. The court’s rules say that images of accused people and plaintiffs cannot be taken without their permission.

item.title: Distracted and Divided, Russian Security Service Misses Threats
item.description: The Ukrainian offensive over the border caught Moscow’s intelligence agencies by surprise, experts say. It wasn’t the first time that has happened during the war.
item.dc:creator: Michael Schwirtz
item.media:credit: David Guttenfelder for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainian men carry a dead Russian soldier in a body bag after finding him in the rubble of a destroyed Russian border post last month.

item.title: American Killed at West Bank Protest Was a Campus Organizer
item.description: Her trip to the West Bank, where she was shot on Friday, was Ms. Eygi’s latest effort in years of activism that began nearly a decade ago when was still a teenager.
item.dc:creator: Ephrat Livni
item.media:description: Aysenur Eygi during her graduation from the University of Washington this year.

item.title: 3 Israelis Dead in Shooting at Allenby Crossing With Jordan, Israel’s Military Says
item.description: The Allenby crossing, near the West Bank city of Jericho, has been the scene of violence in the past.
item.dc:creator: Adam Rasgon
item.media:description: Israeli police officers patroling near the Allenby Bridge crossing between the West Bank and Jordan on Sunday.

item.title: Struggling to Stem Extremism, Tajikistan Hunts Beards and Head Scarves
item.description: After Tajiks were charged with a deadly attack in Moscow, the country has cracked down on signs of Islam. But experts say it’s not addressing the causes of terrorism.
item.dc:creator: Valerie Hopkins and Nanna Heitmann
item.media:credit: Nanna Heitmann for The New York Times
item.media:description: Men taking a break during harvest outside of the village of Qosimobod, Takijistan. The mother of Dalerjon Mirzoyev, one of the suspects charged with the Crocus City Hall attack in March, lives in Qosimobod.

item.title: Family of American Slain in the West Bank Demands an Independent Inquiry
item.description: With witnesses and Palestinian officials accusing Israeli soldiers of firing the fatal shots, “an Israeli investigation is not adequate,” the family said in a statement.
item.dc:creator: Liam Stack and Ephrat Livni
item.media:description: Medics transporting the body of Aysenur Ezgi Eygi, 26, a Turkish American woman who was fatally shot on Friday in the occupied West Bank.

item.title: C.I.A. and MI6 Chiefs Discuss Ukraine’s Incursion Into Russia and Gaza War
item.description: Appearing together publicly for the first time in the history of their agencies, the heads of the U.S. and British intelligence services discussed Ukraine’s incursion into Russia and the war in Gaza.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.media:description: Richard Moore, chief of the British Secret Intelligence Service, left, and William J. Burns, director of the C.I.A., in London on Saturday.

item.title: Ukrainian Forces Block Russian Advance on a Key Eastern Town
item.description: Russia’s drive toward Pokrovsk has stalled along one part of the frontline, but its troops continue to advance in other parts of eastern Ukraine, and its long-range aerial attacks continue.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer
item.media:credit: Nicole Tung for The New York Times
item.media:description: Soldiers of the 33rd Mechanized Brigade fording a river during exercises in the Pokrovsk region last week.

item.title: India’s Epidemic of Cow Vigilantism Unnerves Nation’s Muslims
item.description: An unexpectedly narrow victory at the polls for Prime Minister Narendra Modi and his Hindu-first agenda has not cooled simmering sectarian tensions, as some had hoped.
item.dc:creator: Anupreeta Das and Hari Kumar
item.media:description: Capturing a stray cow in Ayodhya, India, in January. Cows are sacred in Hinduism, especially among its upper castes, and many Indian states ban their slaughter.

item.title: The U.S. Open Concludes
item.description: Let us consider the grief of the lapsed sports fan.
item.dc:creator: Melissa Kirsch

item.title: Online Credit Unions Offering High Interest Rates on Savings May Be Fakes
item.description: Ontario’s financial regulator has issued warnings about three websites illegally claiming to be credit unions, but it is powerless to close them.
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen
item.media:description: An unregistered credit union is nowhere to be found in the Ottawa office tower listed online as its headquarters.

item.title: The Pivotal Decision That Led to a Resurgence of Polio
item.description: In 2016, the global health authorities removed a type of poliovirus from the oral vaccine. The virus caused a growing number of outbreaks and has now arrived in Gaza.
item.dc:creator: Apoorva Mandavilli
item.media:description: A child in Gaza receives the oral polio vaccine. The vaccine’s composition was altered in 2016, with unexpected consequences.

item.title: Meet the Team Climbing Trees in the Amazon to Better Understand Carbon Stores
item.description: A small team in a remote corner of Colombia is surveying every tree in an effort to better understand how much planet-warming carbon the Amazon actually stores.
item.dc:creator: Max Bearak and Federico Rios
item.category: Carbon Caps and Emissions Trading Programs
item.media:description: Data gathered on this tiny site could help researchers improve financial tools to protect forests.

item.title: How Telegram Became a Playground for Criminals, Extremists and Terrorists
item.description: Drug dealers, scammers and white nationalists openly conduct business and spread toxic speech on the platform, according to a Times analysis of more than 3.2 million Telegram messages.
item.dc:creator: Paul Mozur, Adam Satariano, Aaron Krolik and Steven Lee Myers

item.title: West Bank Residents Survey Destruction as Israeli Forces Withdraw
item.description: A 10-day raid by Israeli troops into the occupied territory has been one of the most devastating in years, with at least 39 people killed, according to Palestinian officials.
item.dc:creator: Raja Abdulrahim
item.media:description: Palestinians inspected the damage on Friday after a 10-day Israeli military raid on the West Bank city of Jenin.

item.title: Nell McCafferty, Larger-Than-Life Irish Journalist, Dies at 80
item.description: Her pugnacious writing on women’s rights, gay rights and other issues helped turn her country into one of the most progressive in Europe.
item.dc:creator: Clay Risen

item.title: U.N. Panel Calls for International Force in Sudan to Protect Civilians
item.description: The country’s brutal civil war has led to the killing, rape and torture of civilians, including children, as it threatens to destabilize neighboring countries.
item.dc:creator: Nick Cumming-Bruce
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Ivor Prickett for The New York Times
item.media:description: Sudanese Armed Forces soldiers walking through the heavily destroyed streets of a historic market in Omdurman, Sudan, in April.

item.title: Twitter Changed Soccer. There’s a Risk X Will Do It Again.
item.description: The world’s most popular pastime has been irrevocably shaped by its exposure to social media. That evolution can still go awry.
item.dc:creator: Rory Smith

item.title: American Woman and Palestinian Girl Killed in Separate West Bank Incidents
item.description: In a separate incident, a 13-year-old Palestinian girl was also fatally shot, part of the rising toll of West Bank violence during the war in Gaza.
item.dc:creator: Aaron Boxerman
item.media:description: Medics transporting the body of Aysenur Ezgi Eygi, 26, a Turkish American woman who was fatally shot on Friday in the occupied West Bank.

item.title: Eagles Players Feared Crime in Brazil. Is Philadelphia More Dangerous?
item.description: Some N.F.L. players called Brazil dangerous ahead of the league’s first game in South America on Friday. Statistics show their home city is deadlier.
item.dc:creator: Jack Nicas and Sara Ruberg
item.media:description: A mural featuring quarterbacks from the Philadelphia Eagles and the Green Bay Packers on an apartment tower in São Paulo, Brazil, on Wednesday.

item.title: Ukraine’s Zelensky Presses Western Allies for More Weapons
item.description: The Ukrainian leader argued that escalating military pressure on Russia, combined with diplomacy, was the best way to motivate Moscow to seek peace.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer
item.media:description: From left, Secretary of Defense Lloyd J. Austin III, President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine and the Ukrainian defense minister, Rustem Umerov, met with Western allies in Germany on Friday.

item.title: Hamas’s Release of Hostage Videos Inflames Divisions in Israel
item.description: The fourth recording in as many days of a hostage killed in Gaza has added to pressure on the Israeli government to reach a cease-fire deal with Hamas.
item.dc:creator: Ephrat Livni
item.media:description: Protesters calling for the Israeli government to secure the release of hostages from Gaza, in Tel Aviv on Thursday.

item.title: Qatar’s Crucial Role in the Israel-Hamas Cease-Fire Talks
item.description: The emirate has used its influence with Hamas to press for a truce with Israel. But “the last word is with those on the battlefield,” one expert said.
item.dc:creator: Adam Rasgon and Julian E. Barnes
item.media:description: Prime Minister Mohammed bin Abdulrahman al-Thani of Qatar, center, at a meeting on Gaza this spring in Saudi Arabia. Officials say he has dedicated a great deal of time to brokering a cease-fire.

item.title: Israeli Military Withdraws From Jenin After 10-Day Raid
item.description: The operation killed 21 people, including children, and caused widespread destruction of streets, homes and businesses, according to Palestinian news media and residents.
item.dc:creator: Raja Abdulrahim
item.media:description: Surveying the damage in Jenin, in the Israeli-occupied West Bank, on Friday.

item.title: Against This Mighty Paralympic Team, a Close Loss Can Feel Like a Win
item.description: Other teams give themselves an A for effort after playing the Dutch women’s wheelchair basketball team, the favorite for the gold medal at the Paris Games.
item.dc:creator: Elena Bergeron
item.media:credit: Dmitry Kostyukov for The New York Times
item.media:description: Mariska Beijer of the Netherlands handled the basketball during a game against Spain at the Paralympics in Paris.

item.title: Fire at School Dormitory in Kenya Kills at Least 18 Students
item.description: At least 70 students are still unaccounted for, although officials urged people not to jump to conclusions about their fate.
item.dc:creator: Jimmy Gitaka and Lynsey Chutel
item.media:description: Distressed parents waiting near a burned-out dormitory after a fire at the Hillside Endarasha Primary School in Nyeri County, Kenya.

item.title: Typhoon Yagi Expected to Strengthen Before Hitting Vietnam
item.description: Yagi, one of 2024’s strongest storms, hit the southern Chinese island of Hainan on Friday. It is forecast to make landfall in Vietnam on Saturday.
item.dc:creator: John Yoon and Zixu Wang
item.media:description: Storm clouds gather over Victoria Harbor in Hong Kong on Thursday.

item.title: Is Brisbane Ready to Be the Equal of Sydney and Melbourne?
item.description: Many don’t see Brisbane in the same light as the other two cities, but the Queensland capital is showing it, too, has cultural heft.
item.dc:creator: Julia Bergin
item.media:description: Jean Paul Gaultier’s “Fashion Freak Show,” in Brisbane, Australia.

item.title: China Stops Foreign Adoptions, Ending a Complicated Chapter
item.description: Beijing said the move was in line with international trends, as more countries have limited such adoptions. Many would-be adoptive families were left in limbo.
item.dc:creator: Alexandra Stevenson and Zixu Wang
item.media:description: A child at a foster home on the outskirts of Beijing in 2017.

item.title: Friday Briefing
item.description: Donald Trump’s sentencing on federal charges.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Ahmed Gaber for The New York Times
item.media:description: Justice Juan Merchan has resisted many of Mr. Trump’s most audacious legal maneuvers, and has made clear his intention to be fair to the former president.

item.title: Nurses Win a Bigger Role as Doctors Strike in South Korea
item.description: As hospitals struggle from a monthslong walkout, nurses have picked up some of the slack. A new law gives them more responsibilities and, they say, greater recognition.
item.dc:creator: Jin Yu Young
item.media:description: Members from the Korean Nursing Association celebrating the passing of a bill that gives greater roles and legal protections to nurses.

item.title: Are Pacific Islands a ‘Dumping Ground’ for Accused Priests?
item.description: Over a decades-long period, more than 30 Catholic priests and missionaries moved to remote island nations after they had allegedly abused children in the West, or had been found to do so.
item.dc:creator: Pete McKenzie
item.media:description: Roman Catholic worshipers celebrating Palm Sunday at a church in Dili, East Timor, last year.

item.title: Purported Rembrandt Painting Found in a Maine Attic Sells for $1.4 Million
item.description: “Portrait of a Girl,” a 17th-century work believed to be by the Dutch master, had been hiding in a home in Maine.
item.dc:creator: Claire Moses
item.media:credit: Thomaston Place Auction Galleries, via Associated Press
item.media:description: “Portrait of a Girl,” a painting believed to be by Rembrandt, could become more valuable if it is authenticated.

item.title: Woman in France Testifies Against Husband Accused of Bringing Men to Rape Her
item.description: Gisèle Pelicot spoke of the horror of being told by the police that they had evidence her husband had drugged her for years and brought men into their home to join him in raping her.
item.dc:creator: Catherine Porter
item.media:description: Gisèle Pelicot, 71, arriving at court to testify against her former husband, in Avignon in southern France, on Thursday.

item.title: Anti-Polio Campaign in Gaza Enters New Phase, Hours After Deadly Strike
item.description: As the mass vaccination campaign shifted Thursday from central to southern Gaza, an Israeli strike reportedly killed four in an area where inoculations had just concluded.
item.dc:creator: Lynsey Chutel, Matthew Mpoke Bigg, Lara Jakes and Thomas Fuller
item.media:description: Palestinians lining up to vaccinate their children against polio on Thursday in Khan Younis in the southern Gaza Strip.

item.title: Friday Briefing: A Judge Weighs a Monumental Trump Decision
item.description: Plus, the clothes that changed men’s fashion.
item.dc:creator: Gaya Gupta
item.media:credit: Ahmed Gaber for The New York Times
item.media:description: Justice Juan Merchan outside his office.

item.title: OPEC Plus Delays Plan to Increase Oil Output
item.description: OPEC Plus will extend its cuts until at least December. Demand has weakened, and other countries, including the United States, are expected to continue to increase production.
item.dc:creator: Stanley Reed
item.category: Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries
Abdulaziz bin Salman, Prince of Saudi Arabia
item.media:description: An Aramco oil field in Saudi Arabia, which leads the group of eight nations known as OPEC Plus.

item.title: Russian Military Intelligence Members Indicted Over Ukraine Cyberattack
item.description: The indictment unsealed on Thursday comes as the United States expands its hunt for Russia’s most elite cyberwarriors.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger and Julian E. Barnes
item.media:description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia on Wednesday. The attacks were essentially the opening salvos in the invasion of Ukraine.

item.title: How Much Screen Time Should Toddlers Have? None, Sweden Says.
item.description: Children under the age of 2 should not be exposed to any screens, Swedish public health authorities said, part of a growing effort to limit phone use by youngsters.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.media:description: The Swedish public health authorities recommended this week that children under 2 use no digital media.

item.title: Surprising New Research Links Infant Mortality to Crashing Bat Populations
item.description: Without bats to eat insects, farmers turned to more pesticides, a study found. That appears to have increased infant deaths.
item.dc:creator: Catrin Einhorn
item.media:credit: Kim Raff for The New York Times
item.media:description: The new study shows how human health can suffer when nature is out of balance.

item.title: German Police Shoot Gunman Dead Near Israeli Consulate in Munich
item.description: The shootout with an 18-year-old Austrian came on the anniversary of the attack on the Munich Olympics that left 11 Israelis dead, and was being investigated as a possible terrorist attack.
item.dc:creator: Christopher F. Schuetze
item.category: Documentation Center for the History of National Socialism (Munich, Germany)
item.media:description: Police officers secured the area near the Israeli Consulate in Munich on Thursday.

item.title: U.S. Charges American Commentator Who Works for Russian State TV
item.description: Dimitri K. Simes, who was an adviser to Donald J. Trump’s first campaign, and his wife, Anastasia Simes, are accused of violating U.S. sanctions.
item.dc:creator: Julian E. Barnes and Steven Lee Myers
item.media:description: Dimitri K. Simes with President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia in a photo released by Russian state media. Mr. Simes was accused of violating U.S. sanctions for his work with a state-owned television station.

item.title: Boko Haram Kills at Least 170 Villagers in Nigeria Attack
item.description: Boko Haram killed at least 170 villagers in northeastern Nigeria, community leaders say, in what is likely one of the deadliest attacks in recent years.
item.dc:creator: Ismail Alfa and Ruth Maclean
item.media:description: A funeral in Yobe, Nigeria, on Tuesday for residents killed in the village of Mafa. Thirty-four bodies were brought to the nearest town, but community leaders say many more were buried locally.

item.title: Dismissing Kursk, Putin Says Ukraine’s East Is Russia’s Main Goal
item.description: Dismissing Ukraine’s recent invasion of Kursk, the Russian leader said Kyiv made a mistake in trying to force Moscow to divert its forces from the Donbas region.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora, Anton Troianovski and Nicole Tung
item.media:description: Policemen with the White Angels evacuation team, a special unit of Ukraine’s National Police, assisted in the evacuation of a woman in a village near the frontline in the Pokrovsk district, Ukraine, this week.

item.title: Israeli Raids Become a Near-Daily Reality for Many Palestinians
item.description: As an Israeli offensive against Palestinian militant groups stretched to a 10th day, residents said many people were trapped in their homes out of fear.
item.dc:creator: Raja Abdulrahim
item.media:description: Palestinians inspect a damaged car after an Israeli airstrike in the West Bank city of Tubas on Thursday.

item.title: How Swing State Politics Are Sinking a Global Steel Deal
item.description: As the Biden administration nears a decision to block the proposed acquisition of U.S. Steel, the debate over national and economic security is being dwarfed by presidential politics.
item.dc:creator: Alan Rappeport
item.media:description: A U.S. Steel worker in Clairton, Pa., in 2019. The Biden administration has been under pressure to justify blocking the acquisition of the company amid backlash from the powerful steelworkers’ union.

item.title: Blinken Visits a Haiti Wracked by Corruption and Gangs
item.description: The United States has played a supporting role behind Kenya’s deployment of a security force tasked with helping the Haitian police combat gangs.
item.dc:creator: Michael Crowley
item.media:description: Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken met with Garry Conille, the prime minister of Haiti, in Port-au-Prince on Thursday.

item.title: Macron Names Michel Barnier to Be French Prime Minister, Breaking Impasse
item.description: The president’s choice of Michel Barnier, after an extraordinary delay, inflamed opponents on the left who came out on top in an inconclusive election.
item.dc:creator: Roger Cohen and Aurelien Breeden
item.media:credit: Firas Abdullah/Sipa USA, vía Associated Press
item.media:description: Michel Barnier, 73, is a member of The Republicans, France’s main conservative party.
